qas.question: In very large congregations, what do the elders delegate?

answers.text: practicalities of buildings, finance, and temporal ministry

qas.question: There's a group of officers in the congregation, what other names are they also known by?
The congregation consists of laymen elected by who?
Ruling elders are elected by laymen and ordained to do what?

plausible_answers.text: practicalities of buildings, finance, and temporal ministry

qas.question: Especially in small congregations, elders are known to delegate what?
What is one way a distinct group of laymen is referred to?
Teaching elders are ordained to serve with who?

context: <b3_0><b7_0>Ruling elders<b7_0/><b3_0/> are usually laymen (and laywomen in some denominations) who are elected by <a0_0>the congregation<a0_0/> and ordained to <b4_0>serve with the teaching elders<b4_0/>, assuming responsibility for nurture and leadership of the congregation. Often, especially in larger congregations, the elders delegate the <a1_0><b5_0>practicalities of buildings, finance, and temporal ministry<b5_0/><a1_0/> to the needy in the congregation to a distinct group of officers (sometimes called <a2_0><b6_0>deacons<b6_0/><a2_0/>, which are ordained in some denominations). This group may variously be known as a "Deacon Board", "Board of Deacons" "Diaconate", or "Deacons' Court". These are sometimes known as "presbyters" to the full congregation.
